person.note:
Categories:
People -- Charged with Criminal Activity

note.p: Dewitt Clinton Senter was a Unionist politician in Tennessee during the Civil War who served as governor during Reconstruction.

Born on March 26, 1830, in McMinn County, Tennessee, Senter attended Strawberry Plains College in the early 1850s and studied law. He became active in local politics by the mid-1850s, entering the Tennessee House of Representatives as a Whig in 1855 and serving until the outbreak of the Civil War in 1861. He vehemently opposed secession, and when Tennessee voted to separate from the Union, Senter participated in an effort to have the pro-Union eastern part of the Tennessee conduct its own secession from the rest of the state (similar to the separation of western Virginia counties from their state to make the new state of West Virginia in 1863).

Confederate authorities arrested Senter for his pro-Union sentiments and separatist actions in 1862. Upon release, he moved to Louisville, Kentucky, and joined the Republican Party. He returned to Tennessee in 1865, when it was largely under Union military control, and won election to the state senate.

In 1867, Senter became speaker of the senate. He initially allied with Radical Republican governor William Brownlow. When Brownlow won election to the U.S. Senate in 1869 and vacated the governor’s office, Senter’s role as speaker of the senate placed him next in line for the office. He became governor with a promise to fight rising Ku Klux Klan violence in Tennessee. Within weeks, though, Senter began adjusting his actions. He dissolved the state guard, which had been the primary force opposing the Klan, and advocated for the restoration of rights to former Confederates. His efforts split the Republican Party in Tennessee and led to an effort by Radicals to replace him during the election of 1869. Senter managed to win the election and in 1870 he oversaw a state constitutional convention, which affirmed the right for all men above 21 years of age to vote (regardless of race), but established a poll tax and racially segregated schools.

Senter’s handling of state matters weakened Republican policies in Tennessee and helped white conservative Democrats rebound politically. He lost a majority of support and left politics when his term ended in October 1871. He spent the rest of his life on his farm. Senter died on June 14, 1898. He was married to Harriet Senter and had no children. He is buried in Emma Jarnigan Cemetery in Morristown, Tennessee.
DeWitt Clinton Senter belonged to the following social groups:

Located in Tennessee, Hamilton County was created from Rhea County and Non-County Area 8 and founded on October 25, 1819. The county seat is Chattanooga, Tennessee. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in Davidson County, Nashville was founded in 1780 under the name Nashborough in then Washington District of North Carolina and was renamed Nashville in 1784. On May 26, 1790 it became part of Southwest Territory until the creation of the state of Tennessee on June 1, 1796, when it became part of Davidson County. It was incorporated and became the county seat in 1806, and in 1843, Nashville became the state capital of Tennessee. (Wikipedia; Tennessee Encyclopedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)

While the U.S. Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. U.S. Congress divides legislators into separate committees who write federal or national legislation, and a vast industry of lobbyists also help members write legislation on behalf of corporate and labor interests. Once written, the proposed legislation is introduced to both houses, and if the bill passes both chambers by a majority vote, it is sent to the U.S. President for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and Congress can overcome the President's veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. United States. Congress. An Act respecting fugitives from justice, and persons escaping from the service of their masters (1793)

gloss.p: On February 12, 1793, President George Washington signed the Fugitive Slave Act, requiring states to extradite fugitives from justice within their borders to the states from which they fled. The law covered criminal escapees, but was most notable for empowering slave owners with authority to seize runaway slaves in other states and territories. The law also punished those who aided fugitive slaves or obstructed agents sent to return them to captivity. (Encyclopedia of Virginia)
"The act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The United States Constitution was ratified in 1788 as the foundational code of laws for the United States of America. It was crafted in 1787 by a convention in Philadelphia originally tasked only with amending the existing Articles of Confederation, which had loosely combined the states under a weak central government. Delegates chose to set aside the articles entirely and create a stronger federal government made of three branches: the legislative (comprising two separate parts, the House of Representatives and the Senate), the judicial (led by the Supreme Court), and the executive (headed by the President of the United States). The Constitution sought to carefully balance competing interests regarding state and national authority, as well as large and small state representation. It also created a more direct relationship between Americans and the national government.

The convention’s departure from its original mandate to amend the Articles of Confederation generated controversy, particularly among Americans who opposed placing a distant central authority of the states. The Constitution’s supporters advocated the need for a stronger national government and explained that the federal system preserved state authority for most local matters. To guarantee enough support for ratification, the Constitution’s supporters agreed to add an addendum to more directly protect individuals' specific rights and freedoms. The Constitution was ratified in 1788 and the new United States government began in early 1789. Shortly afterwards, the new Congress adopted several amendments to the Constitution, ten of which were ratified by three-fourths of the states and became known as the Bill of Rights. These first ten amendments guaranteed certain rights for American citizens. Since then, seventeen additional amendments have been ratified to the United States Constitution. Three of them—the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments—were adopted between 1865 and 1870, during the Reconstruction Era. The Thirteenth Amendment formally abolished slavery. The Fourteenth Amendment provides equal protection for all laws and the Fifteenth Amendment protects voting rights for American citizens regardless of “race, color, or previous condition of servitude,” both specifically to combat racial discrimination against African Americans following the end of slavery. (Wikipedia; National Archives and Records Administration)

catDesc.term: Tennessee--Office of the Secretary of State

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Tennessee Secretary of State is elected by the state for a four-year term and is responsible for overseeing state election laws and government records. (Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

element.value: Senter, DeWitt Clinton, 1830-1898

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Alcorn Collection. Legal document from Tennessee Governor DeWitt Clinton Senter to Mississippi Governor James L. Alcorn, concerning the arrest of several men who are fugitives from justice from the State of Tennessee and thought to be in Mississippi. Document also names the individuals sought and the agent of Tennessee whom Governer Senter has authorized to apprehend them.

div.fw: Legal document from Tennessee Governor DeWitt Clinton Senter to Mississippi Governor James L. Alcorn; July 6, 1871
div.p:
The State of Tennessee.
[image: eagle with flag]
TO ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS SHALL COME, GREETING.

Whereas, It has been made to appear that Tim Homer, Thomas. J. Hill, Thomas. S. Giese ^and J. A. Childs.^ of our County of Hamilton—stands charged with the crime of—Grand Larceny.—And it has been represented that they have—fled from the justice of this State, and taken refuge within the State of Mississippi—.

And, Whereas, Agreeably to the provision of the Constitution of the United States, and an Act of Con-gress, passed the twelfth day of February, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-three, application has been duly made to his Excellency, the Governor of—Mississippi—for the delivery of said Tim Homer. Thomas J Hill. Thomas. S. Giese and J. A. Childs. as fugitive from justice: Now, therefore, I, D. W. C. Senter Governor of the State of Tennessee, in pursuance of the power vested in me by law, have appointed, and by these presents I do appoint and commission T. H. Duke. Agent on the part of this State, for the purpose of bringing the said above named parties—into this State, having jurisdiction of the crime aforesaid, whenever the Governor of the said State of Mississippi shall cause him to be delivered up agreeably to the requisition aforesaid.

These are, Therefore, To request and require all persons to permit the said [gap] to receive and secure the said above named parties and bring them unmolested into this State, having jurisdiction of said crime—the said Agent peaceably and lawfully behaving—the State to pay no part of the expense incurred by the execution of this requisition.

p.hi: I have hereunto set my hand and caused to be affixed, the Great Seal of the State of Tennessee.

div.p: Done at the City of Nashville, this 6th day of July., in the year of our Lord, one thousand eight hundred and seventy one of the Independence of the United States, the eighty ninety sixth

[seal: THE GREAT SEAL OF THE STATE OF TENNESSEE
1796
XVI
AGRICULTURE,
COMMERCE]
